nodes.text: Conservation of money as an accounting law and statistical mechanics principles can explain money and income distributions in economies and clarify monetary phenomena
If a conserved additive quantity is exchanged among many agents with time-reversible transaction rules, the equilibrium distribution is exponential (Boltzmann-Gibbs)
Transaction dynamics lacking time-reversal symmetry (e.g., multiplicative percentage transfers) produce non-exponential (Gamma-like or mixed) money distributions
Boundary conditions (e.g., prohibition of unlimited negative money balances) are essential for achieving a stationary money distribution; without such limits debt growth prevents equilibrium
Monetary and physical layers of the economy are distinct: money is an informational conserved token while goods/services are physical and nonconserved; conflating them produces fallacies
The Boltzmann kinetic equation and its Fokker-Planck limit formalize evolution of money distribution using transfer probabilities and moments of transaction size
Empirical income data show a two-class structure: the bulk follows an exponential distribution and the high-income tail follows a power law (Pareto)
Agent-based simulations starting from equal initial money and imposing m>0 evolve to an exponential stationary distribution due to entropy increase
Allowing unrestricted debt (net worth as variable) removes the lower boundary and leads to indefinite broadening of the distribution, i.e., no equilibrium
Interest and accumulation of debt destabilize distributions further; systemic synchronization of defaults can trigger large crises (Minsky moment)
Lending and bank-created deposits are best characterized as creation of debt obligations, not exogenous money; commercial banks create debt/liabilities paired with assets
Central banks and the state can inject exogenous money (vertical transactions), changing total money in the private system and affecting prices and distribution

Quantitative easing and large-scale central bank interventions direct new money toward financial institutions and empirically coincide with increased income share of the upper class, raising inequality

The lend-crash-bailout cycle (bank-created debt followed by central bank monetization in crises) concentrates gains in private finance and socializes losses, so state money is the ultimate source enabling aggregate profit and interest

Policy and model implications: (a) models must keep money explicitly to study monetary crises, (b) regulation or boundary conditions on debt are required for stability, and (c) distinguishing monetary vs physical layers improves conceptual clarity
